awd_titl_txt: EAGER: A Model System for Soil Microbial Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit:
Microbial communities govern the nutrient cycles, integrity of solid surfaces, and health of other organisms in essentially every habitat on Earth. To affect these processes towards improving the health of animals, plants, or the planet itself, it is necessary to understand what makes communities resistant and also susceptible to change. For example, soil communities influence crop health and global climate, and yet little is known about the principles governing stability and change in this habitat. This project will enable an investigation of the nature of community robustness - the resistance to, and recovery from disturbance. One especially interesting aspect of robustness is invasion. Towards understanding the traits that make bacteria successful community invaders, and conversely, the traits of communities that enable them to exclude invaders, a simple model system is required, in which variables can be controlled and genetic analysis can be applied. This project focuses on the microbial community associated with sand grains in soil for several reasons, including the relative uniformity of sand particles, the disaggregated nature of sand (compared with other soil components), the aerobic nature of sand-associated communities, exposure of sand communities to invaders, and the ease of manipulation of sand grains as experimental units. Thus, laying the groundwork for identifying genes and metabolites that influence invasion and exclusion, a model community, together with appropriate bacterial invaders, will be designed and developed.

Broader Impacts:
This project will provide research opportunities for undergraduates. A valued resource that will be relied upon to increase participation of ethnically diverse students in the project is the POSSE Program. This is a national program that recruits outstanding high school students to attend college as a cohort. POSSE students have a remarkably high graduation rate and they are truly exceptional scholars. This project will provide summer research experiences at Yale for POSSE students from other institutions, to be mentored by individuals trained in principles and practices of successful mentoring.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The last decade of research has generated an explosion of knowledge about microbiomes—the communities of microorganisms that live in every habitat on Earth, from the human skin and nose, to the fur of sloths to deep sea vents to rocks atop the highest mountains. Recent findings indicate that microbiomes are more essential to health of people and the planet we inhabit than ever suspected, and yet fundamental aspects of microbiome function remains unexplored and unknown.  One reason is that microbiomes are complex, sometimes containing as many as 5,000 species in a dynamic relationship with each other and the surrounding environment.  In order to understand these ecosystems, we need simple models conducive to asking mechanistic questions.

The history of biological research is rich with model systems—organisms that can be used as stand-ins for less easily studied organisms.  For example, E. coli, a model for fundamental processes such as gene structure and expression, has transformed understanding of all organisms.  Similarly, nematodes (microscopic worms) have been used to dissect the process of cell differentiation, producing knowledge relevant to people and many human diseases.  The scientific advances made in these model systems couldn't have been made in more complex systems because of the practical and ethical challenges of isolating variables.  Similarly, microbiomes will never be fully understood through the study of complex communities in soil or the human gut because of the massive array of variables that must be accommodated.  It's time to develop a simple model system for microbial communities that will inform microbiomes in diverse habitats.

In this project, we constructed a model community of soil bacteria that is amenable to study.  We included three members, representing the three major groups of bacteria in both soil and human gut, and have developed tools to study the members using genomics, genetic analysis, and microscopic methods.  Our studies show that the community comprised of the three organisms has characteristics that cannot be explained by the additive effects of the individual members.  The community creates more biomass in “biofilms”—organized networks of bacteria— than any of the members singly or in pairs.  One key behavior of communities that remains obscure is invasion, a process that is critical to the health and demise of communities and our ability to change communities for desirable outcomes.  For example, if we are to be able to use probiotics (bacteria) as treatments for ailments affected by the human gut microbiome (obesity, diabetes, heart disease, and certain cancers) it will be essential that the probiotics invade or establish themselves in the gut community.  But for 100 years, the processes of successful invasion and ability of a community to resist invasion have eluded scientific understanding.  The model community that we developed is ideal for studying this process.  We showed that certain species of bacteria can invade the model community and other species cannot.  Our approach is to genes responsible invasion as well as those involved in making a community able to resist invasion.

The studies based on this model system have the potential to change biology by making it possible to dissect community behaviors as we've done with cell and organism biology.

Broader Impacts

To teach about microbial communities to a broad audience, we developed the Small World Initiative—a worldwide network of educators who teach a college research course aimed at discovering new antibiotics.  The course provides students with the opportunity for original thinking and scientific discovery, capturing the very aspects of science that hook many scientists on their craft.  Students learn the way practicing scientists learn because the course asks students to be scientists for a semester rather than just learn about science that others have discovered.  Students are motivated by curiosity as well as a desire to contribute to solving a global health threat created by the diminishing panel of effective antibiotics to treat human infectious disease.  A key innovation of the last year of the project was to collaborate with high school teachers whose students sent soil samples to the college students, who developed ongoing relationships with the high school students, updating them regularly as the research on their soil progressed.

The Small World Initiative addresses several societal needs.  First, it encourages students to persist in STEM majors at a time when there is a shortage of technically trained college graduates to meet workforce needs.  Second, it is focused on discovering new antibiotics at a time when they are desperately needed but not on the agenda of the pharmaceutical industry.  Third, it provides a vehicle for forging collaborations between college and high school students, engaging the high school students in research and requiring college students to teach others about their research projects.  This valuable set of objectives has driven the popularity of the Small World Initiative among students and faculty, resulting in an expanding and enthusiastic network.
